title: Emotional scene as Yankees react to the end of their season
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: The Houston Astros are returning to the World Series for the second time in three years after defeating the Yankees, but must go through a red-hot Nationals team if they want to hoist the trophy. USA TODAY

HOUSTON – Almost 20 minutes after Joe Altuve’s home run ended the Yankees’ year, their clubhouse was still somber and quiet.

Teammates hugged, coaches consoled players and manager Aaron Boone went around the room, his eyes red, stopping at each locker and offering an individual word of praise and thanks.

In Game 6, just in the ninth inning alone, the Yankees were down and then even and then out, a whiplash of emotions at Minute Maid Park.

There wasn’t another game to prepare for. This was goodbye to 2019.

“During the season, when you lose, you always have a chance to come back tomorrow and redeem yourself and get back headed in the right direction,’’ Brett Gardner said. “At this time of the year, only one team goes home happy.’’

And this heartfelt scene on Saturday night, after the Astros’ pennant-winning 6-4 victory, was “just seeing the end of a really special season.’’

Gleyber Torres #25 of the New York Yankees reacts against the Houston Astros during the eighth inning in game six of the American League Championship Series at Minute Maid Park on October 19, 2019 in Houston, Texas. (Photo: Elsa, Getty Images)

Talking it out

Boone had addressed the team one final time, talking about a club that couldn’t be defined by wins or losses but “by how we got up,’’ said Aaron Judge, who still took the AL Championship Series loss as a personal one in some respects.

Judge said it was his responsibility to “try to do whatever I can to put our team in a better position to win,’’ and as “a leader of this team, I’ve got to step up, I’ve got to do something about that.’’

Collectively, that something they couldn’t do as well as the Astros was hit with runners in scoring position; they were 2-for-22 in that category since the 11th inning of Game 2.

And though Judge had said that “no matter how many games we won in the regular season or anything else we did, the season’s a failure,’’ he was no less proud of the effort.

“Even guys who aren’t here (in the clubhouse) today who put us in this position, they gave us all they had,’’ Judge said. “Think of CC (Sabathia), he pitched ‘til his arm blew out.

“I think of a lot of guys (who) just left it all on the field. Nothing to hang your head about.

“This time we didn’t get the job done when it counted.’’

Members of the New York Yankees watch during the ninth inning in Game 6 of baseball's American League Championship Series against the Houston Astros Saturday, Oct. 19, 2019, in Houston. (Photo: Matt Slocum, AP)

Praise, regret, uncertainty

There was plenty of respectful given to Altuve and the Astros, mixed with the fresh memory of Yankees chances that weren’t seized.

"It's fun to come in here and see everybody working toward the same goal,'' said J.A. Happ. "We won a lot of games this year. And we expected to win (six) more than we did.''

Yet, this was the club that put a record-setting amount of players on the injured list and took its Next Man Up theme to ALCS Game 6.

“In a lot of ways, it was a very successful year, a very positive year,’’ said D.J. LeMahieu, whose game-tying, two-run homer with one out in the ninth had briefly resuscitated hope of a Game 7. “But it’s not the ending we wanted.’’

“It’s a tough way to end a year,’’ said Zack Britton. “You don’t know how often you’re going to get a chance to do stuff like this as a team.’’

And the team will change some next season; Sabathia walked out of the clubhouse and into retirement, while pending free agents in Gardner, Didi Gregorius, Dellin Betances and Cameron Maybin face uncertain futures.

Aroldis Chapman, who threw the final pitch, might opt out of his contract.

"But the work never ends,’’ said Boone. “We’ll continue to try and, I guess, close that gap.

“I know everyone in our room believes we will and we’ll have a lot of battle scars when we do finally get to the top of that mountain.’’
description: After a whiplash of emotions in the ninth inning of ALCS Game 6 Saturday, the Yankees try to come to grips with their season's end.
